subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that array initialization contains a trailing comma.
By default, the check demands a comma at the end if neither left nor right curly braces are on the same line as the last element of the array.

Rationale: Putting this comma in makes it easier to change the order of the elements or add new elements on the end. Main benefit of a trailing comma is that when you add new entry to an array, no surrounding lines are changed.
If closing brace is on the same line as trailing comma, this benefit is gone (as the check does not demand a certain location of curly braces the following two cases will not produce a violation):
If opening brace is on the same line as trailing comma there's also (more arguable) problem:

tr.td: Control whether to always check for a trailing comma, even when an array is inline.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="ArrayTrailingComma"/>
subsection.p: Which results in the following violations:
To configure check to always validate trailing comma:
subsection.source: <module name="ArrayTrailingComma"> <property name="alwaysDemandTrailingComma" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Detects double brace initialization.

Rationale: Double brace initialization (set of
Instance Initializers in class body) may look cool, but it is considered as anti-pattern and should be avoided. This is also can lead to a hard-to-detect memory leak, if the anonymous class instance is returned outside and other object(s) hold reference to it. Created anonymous class is not static, it holds an implicit reference to the outer class instance. See this
blog post and
article for more details. Check ignores any comments and semicolons in class body.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="AvoidDoubleBraceInitialization"/>
subsection.p: Which results in the following violations:

Check only looks for double brace initialization and it ignores cases where the anonymous class has fields or methods. Though these might create the same memory issues as double brace, the extra class members can produce side effects if changed incorrectly.

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Detects inline conditionals. Here is one example of an inline conditional:
subsection.source: String a = getParameter("a"); String b = (a==null || a.length()<1) ? null : a.substring(1);
subsection.p: Rationale: Some developers find inline conditionals hard to read, so their employer's coding standards forbid them.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="AvoidInlineConditionals"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks if call to superclass constructor without arguments is present. Such invocation is redundant because constructor body implicitly begins with a superclass constructor invocation super(); See specification for detailed information.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="AvoidNoArgumentSuperConstructorCall"/>
subsection.p: Example of violations

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that classes and records which define a covariant equals() method also override method equals(Object).
Covariant equals() - method that is similar to equals(Object), but with a covariant parameter type (any subtype of Object).

Notice: the enums are also checked, even though they cannot override equals(Object). The reason is to point out that implementing equals() in enums is considered an awful practice: it may cause having two different enum values that are equal using covariant enum method, and not equal when compared normally.
Inspired by Finding Bugs is Easy, chapter '4.5 Bad Covariant Definition of Equals (Eq)':

Java classes and records may override the equals(Object) method to define a predicate for object equality. This method is used by many of the Java runtime library classes; for example, to implement generic containers.
Programmers sometimes mistakenly use the type of their class Foo as the type of the parameter to equals():
subsection.source: public boolean equals(Foo obj) {...}
subsection.p: This covariant version of equals() does not override the version in the Object class, and it may lead to unexpected behavior at runtime, especially if the class is used with one of the standard collection classes which expect that the standard equals(Object) method is overridden.

This kind of bug is not obvious because it looks correct, and in circumstances where the class is accessed through the references of the class type (rather than a supertype), it will work correctly. However, the first time it is used in a container, the behavior might be mysterious. For these reasons, this type of bug can elude testing and code inspections.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="CovariantEquals"/>
subsection.p: For example:
The same class without violations:
Another example:
The same record without violations:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p:
Checks that the parts of a class, record, or interface declaration appear in the order suggested by the
Code Conventions for the Java Programming Language.
According to Code Conventions for the Java Programming Language , the parts of a class or interface declaration should appear in the following order:

ol.li: Class (static) variables. First the public class variables, then protected, then package level (no access modifier), and then private.
Instance variables. First the public class variables, then protected, then package level (no access modifier), and then private.

subsection.p: Purpose of ignore* option is to ignore related violations, however it still impacts on other class members.

ATTENTION: the check skips class fields which have
forward references from validation due to the fact that we have Checkstyle's limitations to clearly detect user intention of fields location and grouping. For example:

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="DeclarationOrder"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to ignore validation of constructors:
subsection.source: <module name="DeclarationOrder"> <property name="ignoreConstructors" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to ignore modifiers:
subsection.source: <module name="DeclarationOrder"> <property name="ignoreModifiers" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Check that the default is after all the cases in a switch statement.
Rationale: Java allows default anywhere within the switch statement. But it is more readable if it comes after the last case.

tr.td: Control whether to allow default along with case if they are not last.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="DefaultComesLast"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to allow default label to be not last if it is shared with case:
subsection.source: <module name="DefaultComesLast"> <property name="skipIfLastAndSharedWithCase" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Detects empty statements (standalone ";" semicolon). Empty statements often introduce bugs that are hard to spot

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="EmptyStatement"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that any combination of String literals is on the left side of an equals() comparison. Also checks for String literals assigned to some field (such as someString.equals(anotherString = "text")).

Rationale: Calling the equals() method on String literals will avoid a potential NullPointerException. Also, it is pretty common to see null checks right before equals comparisons but following this rule such checks are not required.

tr.td: Control whether to ignore String.equalsIgnoreCase(String) invocations.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="EqualsAvoidNull"/>
subsection.p: Example:
subsection.source: String nullString = null; nullString.equals("My_Sweet_String"); // violation "My_Sweet_String".equals(nullString); // OK nullString.equalsIgnoreCase("My_Sweet_String"); // violation "My_Sweet_String".equalsIgnoreCase(nullString); // OK
subsection.p: To configure the check to allow ignoreEqualsIgnoreCase:
subsection.source: <module name="EqualsAvoidNull"> <property name="ignoreEqualsIgnoreCase" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
subsection.source: String nullString = null; nullString.equals("My_Sweet_String"); // violation "My_Sweet_String".equals(nullString); // OK nullString.equalsIgnoreCase("My_Sweet_String"); // OK "My_Sweet_String".equalsIgnoreCase(nullString); // OK

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that classes that either override equals() or hashCode() also overrides the other. This check only verifies that the method declarations match Object.equals(Object) and Object.hashCode() exactly to be considered an override. This check does not verify invalid method names, parameters other than Object, or anything else.

Rationale: The contract of equals() and hashCode() requires that equal objects have the same hashCode. Therefore, whenever you override equals() you must override hashCode() to ensure that your class can be used in hash-based collections.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="EqualsHashCode"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks if any class or object member is explicitly initialized to default for its type value (null for object references, zero for numeric types and char and false for boolean.

Rationale: Each instance variable gets initialized twice, to the same value. Java initializes each instance variable to its default value (0 or null) before performing any initialization specified in the code. So there is a minor inefficiency.

tr.td: control whether only explicit initializations made to null for objects should be checked.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="ExplicitInitialization"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check so that it only checks for objects that explicitly initialize to null:
subsection.source: <module name="ExplicitInitialization"> <property name="onlyObjectReferences" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks for fall-through in switch statements. Finds locations where a case contains Java code but lacks a break, return, throw or continue statement.

The check honors special comments to suppress the warning. By default, the texts "fallthru", "fall thru", "fall-thru", "fallthrough", "fall through", "fall-through" "fallsthrough", "falls through", "falls-through" (case-sensitive). The comment containing these words must be all on one line, and must be on the last non-empty line before the case triggering the warning or on the same line before the case (ugly, but possible).
Note: The check assumes that there is no unreachable code in the case.

tr.td: Control whether the last case group must be checked.
Define the RegExp to match the relief comment that suppresses the warning about a fall through.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="FallThrough"/>
subsection.p: Example:
Example how to suppress violations by comment:
To configure the check to enable check for last case group:
subsection.source: <module name="FallThrough"> <property name="checkLastCaseGroup" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check with custom relief pattern:
subsection.source: <module name="FallThrough"> <property name="reliefPattern" value="FALL?[ -]?THROUGH"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that local variables that never have their values changed are declared final. The check can be configured to also check that unchanged parameters are declared final.

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p: When configured to check parameters, the check ignores parameters of interface methods and abstract methods.

tr.td:
Control whether to check
enhanced for-loop variable.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="FinalLocalVariable"/>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it checks local variables and parameters:
subsection.source: <module name="FinalLocalVariable"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF,PARAMETER_DEF"/> </module>
subsection.p:
By default, this Check skip final validation on
Enhanced For-Loop.
Option 'validateEnhancedForLoopVariable' could be used to make Check to validate even variable from Enhanced For Loop.
An example of how to configure the check so that it also validates enhanced For Loop Variable is:
subsection.source: <module name="FinalLocalVariable"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF"/> <property name="validateEnhancedForLoopVariable" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
An example of how to configure check on local variables and parameters but do not validate loop variables:
subsection.source: <module name="FinalLocalVariable"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF,PARAMETER_DEF"/> <property name="validateEnhancedForLoopVariable" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that a local variable or a parameter does not shadow a field that is defined in the same class.

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p: It is possible to configure the check to ignore all property setter methods.
A method is recognized as a setter if it is in the following form
subsection.source: ${returnType} set${Name}(${anyType} ${name}) { ... }
subsection.p: where ${anyType} is any primitive type, class or interface name; ${name} is name of the variable that is being set and ${Name} its capitalized form that appears in the method name. By default, it is expected that setter returns void, i.e. ${returnType} is 'void'. For example
subsection.source: void setTime(long time) { ... }
subsection.p: Any other return types will not let method match a setter pattern. However, by setting setterCanReturnItsClass property to true definition of a setter is expanded, so that setter return type can also be a class in which setter is declared. For example
Such methods are known as chain-setters and a common when Builder-pattern is used. Property setterCanReturnItsClass has effect only if ignoreSetter is set to true.

tr.td: Define the RegExp for names of variables and parameters to ignore.
Control whether to ignore constructor parameters.
Allow to ignore the parameter of a property setter method.
Allow to expand the definition of a setter method to include methods that return the class' instance.
Control whether to ignore parameters of abstract methods.
subset of tokens VARIABLE_DEF , PARAMETER_DEF , PATTERN_VARIABLE_DEF , LAMBDA , RECORD_COMPONENT_DEF .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="HiddenField"/>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it checks local variables but not parameters:
subsection.source: <module name="HiddenField"> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it ignores the variables and parameters named "test":
subsection.source: <module name="HiddenField"> <property name="ignoreFormat" value="^testField"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it ignores constructor parameters:
subsection.source: <module name="HiddenField"> <property name="ignoreConstructorParameter" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it ignores the parameter of setter methods:
subsection.source: <module name="HiddenField"> <property name="ignoreSetter" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it ignores the parameter of setter methods recognizing setter as returning either void or a class in which it is declared:
subsection.source: <module name="HiddenField"> <property name="ignoreSetter" value="true"/> <property name="setterCanReturnItsClass" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it ignores parameters of abstract methods:
subsection.source: <module name="HiddenField"> <property name="ignoreAbstractMethods" value="true"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that certain exception types do not appear in a catch statement.

Rationale: catching java.lang.Exception, java.lang.Error or java.lang.RuntimeException is almost never acceptable. Novice developers often simply catch Exception in an attempt to handle multiple exception classes. This unfortunately leads to code that inadvertently catches NullPointerException, OutOfMemoryError, etc.

tr.td: Specify exception class names to reject.

td.code: Error, Exception, RuntimeException, Throwable, java.lang.Error, java.lang.Exception, java.lang.RuntimeException, java.lang.Throwable

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalCatch"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to override the default list with ArithmeticException and OutOfMemoryError:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalCatch"> <property name="illegalClassNames" value="ArithmeticException, OutOfMemoryError"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks for illegal instantiations where a factory method is preferred.
Rationale: Depending on the project, for some classes it might be preferable to create instances through factory methods rather than calling the constructor.

A simple example is the java.lang.Boolean class. For performance reasons, it is preferable to use the predefined constants TRUE and FALSE. Constructor invocations should be replaced by calls to Boolean.valueOf().
Some extremely performance sensitive projects may require the use of factory methods for other classes as well, to enforce the usage of number caches or object pools.

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p: There is a limitation that it is currently not possible to specify array classes.

tr.td: Specify fully qualified class names that should not be instantiated.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalInstantiation"/>
subsection.p: Example:

To configure the check to find instantiations of java.lang.Boolean and java.lang.Integer. NOTE: Even if property tokens is completely removed from the following configuration, Checkstyle will produce the same results for violation. This is because if property tokens is not defined in the configuration, Checkstyle will supply it with list of default tokens CLASS_DEF, LITERAL_NEW, PACKAGE_DEF, IMPORT for this check. The property is defined in this example only to provide clarity:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalInstantiation"> <property name="classes" value="java.lang.Boolean, java.lang.Integer"/> <property name="tokens" value="CLASS_DEF, LITERAL_NEW, PACKAGE_DEF, IMPORT"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

To configure the check to allow violations for local classes vs classes defined in the check, for example java.lang.Boolean, property tokens must be defined to not mention CLASS_DEF, so its value should be LITERAL_NEW, PACKAGE_DEF, IMPORT:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalInstantiation"> <property name="classes" value="java.lang.Boolean, java.lang.Integer"/> <property name="tokens" value="LITERAL_NEW, PACKAGE_DEF, IMPORT"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
Finally, there is a limitation that it is currently not possible to specify array classes:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalInstantiation"> <property name="classes" value="java.lang.Boolean[], Boolean[], java.lang.Integer[], Integer[]"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that specified types are not declared to be thrown. Declaring that a method throws java.lang.Error or java.lang.RuntimeException is almost never acceptable.

tr.td: Specify throw class names to reject.

td.code: Error, RuntimeException, Throwable, java.lang.Error, java.lang.RuntimeException, java.lang.Throwable

tr.td: Specify names of methods to ignore.
allow to ignore checking overridden methods (marked with Override or java.lang.Override annotation).

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalThrows"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check rejecting throws NullPointerException from methods:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalThrows"> <property name="illegalClassNames" value="NullPointerException"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check ignoring method named "func1()":
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalThrows"> <property name="ignoredMethodNames" value="func1"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to warn on overridden methods:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalThrows"> <property name="ignoreOverriddenMethods" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks for illegal tokens. By default, labels are prohibited.

Rationale: Certain language features can harm readability, lead to confusion or are not obvious to novice developers. Other features may be discouraged in certain frameworks, such as not having native methods in Enterprise JavaBeans components.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalToken"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to report violation on token LITERAL_NATIVE:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalToken"> <property name="tokens" value="LITERAL_NATIVE"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks specified tokens text for matching an illegal pattern. By default, no tokens are specified.

tr.td: Define the RegExp for illegal pattern.
Control whether to ignore case when matching.
Define the message which is used to notify about violations; if empty then the default message is used.

subset of tokens
NUM_DOUBLE , NUM_FLOAT , NUM_INT , NUM_LONG , IDENT , COMMENT_CONTENT , STRING_LITERAL , CHAR_LITERAL , TEXT_BLOCK_CONTENT .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check to forbid String literals containing "a href":
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalTokenText"> <property name="tokens" value="STRING_LITERAL"/> <property name="format" value="a href"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to forbid String literals containing "a href" for the ignoreCase mode:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalTokenText"> <property name="tokens" value="STRING_LITERAL"/> <property name="format" value="a href"/> <property name="ignoreCase" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to forbid string literal text blocks containing """:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalTokenText"> <property name="tokens" value="TEXT_BLOCK_CONTENT"/> <property name="format" value='"'/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to forbid leading zeros in an integer literal, other than zero and a hex literal:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalTokenText"> <property name="tokens" value="NUM_INT,NUM_LONG"/> <property name="format" value="^0[^lx]"/> <property name="ignoreCase" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
subsection.source: public void myTest() { int test1 = 0; // OK int test2 = 0x111; // OK int test3 = 0X111; // OK, case is ignored int test4 = 010; // violation long test5 = 0L; // OK long test6 = 010L; // violation }

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that particular classes or interfaces are never used.
Rationale: Helps reduce coupling on concrete classes.
For additional restriction of type usage see also: IllegalInstantiation, IllegalImport

tr.td: Control whether to validate abstract class names.
Specify classes that should not be used as types in variable declarations, return values or parameters.

td.code: HashMap, HashSet, LinkedHashMap, LinkedHashSet, TreeMap, TreeSet, java.util.HashMap, java.util.HashSet, java.util.LinkedHashMap, java.util.LinkedHashSet, java.util.TreeMap, java.util.TreeSet

tr.td: Define abstract classes that may be used as types.
Specify methods that should not be checked.
Specify RegExp for illegal abstract class names.
Control whether to check only methods and fields with any of the specified modifiers. This property does not affect method calls nor method references nor record components.

subset of tokens
ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF , CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , METHOD_CALL , METHOD_DEF , METHOD_REF , PARAMETER_DEF , VARIABLE_DEF , PATTERN_VARIABLE_DEF , RECORD_DEF , RECORD_COMPONENT_DEF .
ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF , CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , METHOD_CALL , METHOD_DEF , METHOD_REF , PARAMETER_DEF , VARIABLE_DEF , PATTERN_VARIABLE_DEF , RECORD_DEF , RECORD_COMPONENT_DEF .

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p:
It is possible to set illegal class names via short or
canonical name. Specifying illegal type invokes analyzing imports and Check puts violations at corresponding declarations (of variables, methods or parameters). This helps to avoid ambiguous cases, e.g.: java.awt.List was set as illegal class name, then, code like:
will be ok.
In most cases it's justified to put following classes to illegalClassNames:
as methods that are differ from interface methods are rarely used, so in most cases user will benefit from checking for them.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the default check:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalType"/>
subsection.p: To configure the Check so that particular tokens are checked:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalType"> <property name="tokens" value="METHOD_DEF"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the Check so that it ignores function() methods:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalType"> <property name="ignoredMethodNames" value="function"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the Check so that it validates abstract class names:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalType"> <property name="validateAbstractClassNames" value="true"/> <property name="illegalAbstractClassNameFormat" value="Gitt"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the Check so that it verifies only public, protected or static methods and fields:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalType"> <property name="memberModifiers" value="LITERAL_PUBLIC, LITERAL_PROTECTED, LITERAL_STATIC"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the check so that it verifies usage of types Boolean and Foo:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalType"> <property name="illegalClassNames" value="Boolean, Foo"/> </module>
subsection.p: To configure the check to target fields types only:
subsection.source: <module name="IllegalType"> <property name="illegalClassNames" value="java.util.Optional"/> <property name="tokens" value="VARIABLE_DEF"/> <property name="id" value="IllegalTypeOptionalAsField"/> </module> <module name="SuppressionXpathSingleFilter"> <property name="query" value="//METHOD_DEF//*"/> <property name="id" value="IllegalTypeOptionalAsField"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks for assignments in subexpressions, such as in String s = Integer.toString(i = 2);.

Rationale: Except for the loop idioms, all assignments should occur in their own top-level statement to increase readability. With inner assignments like the one given above, it is difficult to see all places where a variable is set.
Note: Check allows usage of the popular assignments in loops:

Assignment inside a condition is not a problem here, as the assignment is surrounded by an extra pair of parentheses. The comparison is != null and there is no chance that intention was to write line == reader.readLine().

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="InnerAssignment"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p:
Checks that there are no
"magic numbers" where a magic number is a numeric literal that is not defined as a constant. By default, -1, 0, 1, and 2 are not considered to be magic numbers.
Constant definition is any variable/field that has 'final' modifier. It is fine to have one constant defining multiple numeric literals within one expression:

tr.td: Ignore magic numbers in hashCode methods.
Ignore magic numbers in annotation declarations.
Ignore magic numbers in field declarations.
Ignore magic numbers in annotation elements defaults.
Specify tokens that are allowed in the AST path from the number literal to the enclosing constant definition.
ARRAY_INIT , ASSIGN , DIV , ELIST , EXPR , LITERAL_NEW , METHOD_CALL , MINUS , PLUS , STAR , TYPECAST , UNARY_MINUS , UNARY_PLUS

subset of tokens
NUM_DOUBLE , NUM_FLOAT , NUM_INT , NUM_LONG .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check with default configuration:
subsection.source: <module name="MagicNumber"/>
subsection.p: results is following violations:
To configure the check so that it checks floating-point numbers that are not 0, 0.5, or 1:
subsection.source: <module name="MagicNumber"> <property name="tokens" value="NUM_DOUBLE, NUM_FLOAT"/> <property name="ignoreNumbers" value="0, 0.5, 1"/> <property name="ignoreFieldDeclaration" value="true"/> <property name="ignoreAnnotation" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: results is following violations:
To configure the check so that it ignores magic numbers in field declarations:
subsection.source: <module name="MagicNumber"> <property name="ignoreFieldDeclaration" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: results in the following violations:
To configure the check to check annotation element defaults:
subsection.source: <module name="MagicNumber"> <property name="ignoreAnnotationElementDefaults" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: results in following violations:
Config example of constantWaiverParentToken option:
subsection.source: <module name="MagicNumber"> <property name="constantWaiverParentToken" value="ASSIGN,ARRAY_INIT,EXPR, UNARY_PLUS, UNARY_MINUS, TYPECAST, ELIST, DIV, PLUS "/> </module>
subsection.p: result is following violation:
subsection.source: class TestMethodCall { public void method2() { final TestMethodCall dummyObject = new TestMethodCall(62); //violation final int a = 3; // ok as waiver is ASSIGN final int [] b = {4, 5} // ok as waiver is ARRAY_INIT final int c = -3; // ok as waiver is UNARY_MINUS final int d = +4; // ok as waiver is UNARY_PLUS final int e = method(1, 2) // ELIST is there but violation due to METHOD_CALL final int x = 3 * 4; // violation final int y = 3 / 4; // ok as waiver is DIV final int z = 3 + 4; // ok as waiver is PLUS final int w = 3 - 4; // violation final int x = (int)(3.4); //ok as waiver is TYPECAST } }
subsection.p: Config example of ignoreHashCodeMethod option:
subsection.source: <module name="MagicNumber"> <property name="ignoreHashCodeMethod" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: result is no violation:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Evaluates Xpath query and report violation on all matching AST nodes. This check allows user to implement custom checks using Xpath. If Xpath query is not specified explicitly, then the check does nothing.

It is recommended to define custom message for violation to explain what is not allowed and what to use instead, default message might be too abstract. To customize a message you need to add message element with matchxpath.match as key attribute and desired message as value attribute.

Please read more about Xpath syntax at Xpath Syntax. Information regarding Xpath functions can be found at XSLT/XPath Reference. Note, that @text attribute can be used only with token types that are listed in
XpathUtil.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: Checkstyle provides command line tool and GUI application with options to show AST and to ease usage of Xpath queries.
-T option prints AST tree of the checked file.
subsection.source: $ java -jar checkstyle-X.XX-all.jar -T Main.java CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [1:0] |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [1:0] | `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [1:0] |--LITERAL_CLASS -> class [1:7] |--IDENT -> Main [1:13] `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [1:18] |--LCURLY -> { [1:18] |--METHOD_DEF -> METHOD_DEF [2:4] | |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [2:4] | | `--LITERAL_PUBLIC -> public [2:4] | |--TYPE -> TYPE [2:11] | | `--IDENT -> String [2:11] | |--IDENT -> sayHello [2:18] | |--LPAREN -> ( [2:26] | |--PARAMETERS -> PARAMETERS [2:27] | | `--PARAMETER_DEF -> PARAMETER_DEF [2:27] | | |--MODIFIERS -> MODIFIERS [2:27] | | |--TYPE -> TYPE [2:27] | | | `--IDENT -> String [2:27] | | `--IDENT -> name [2:34] | |--RPAREN -> ) [2:38] | `--SLIST -> { [2:40] | |--LITERAL_RETURN -> return [3:8] | | |--EXPR -> EXPR [3:25] | | | `--PLUS -> + [3:25] | | | |--STRING_LITERAL -> "Hello, " [3:15] | | | `--IDENT -> name [3:27] | | `--SEMI -> ; [3:31] | `--RCURLY -> } [4:4] `--RCURLY -> } [5:0]
subsection.p: -b option shows AST nodes that match given Xpath query. This command can be used to validate accuracy of Xpath query against given file.
subsection.source: $ java -jar checkstyle-X.XX-all.jar Main.java -b "//METHOD_DEF[./IDENT[@text='sayHello']]" CLASS_DEF -> CLASS_DEF [1:0] `--OBJBLOCK -> OBJBLOCK [1:18] |--METHOD_DEF -> METHOD_DEF [2:4]
subsection.p: The following example demonstrates validation of methods order, so that public methods should come before the private ones:
subsection.source: <module name="MatchXpath"> <property name="query" value="//METHOD_DEF[.//LITERAL_PRIVATE and following-sibling::METHOD_DEF[.//LITERAL_PUBLIC]]"/> <message key="matchxpath.match" value="Private methods must appear after public methods"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To violate if there are any parametrized constructors
subsection.source: <module name="MatchXpath"> <property name="query" value="//CTOR_DEF[count(./PARAMETERS/*) > 0]"/> <message key="matchxpath.match" value="Parameterized constructors are not allowed, there should be only default ctor"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To violate if method name is 'test' or 'foo'
subsection.source: <module name="MatchXpath"> <property name="query" value="//METHOD_DEF[./IDENT[@text='test' or @text='foo']]"/> <message key="matchxpath.match" value="Method name should not be 'test' or 'foo'"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To violate if new instance creation was done without var type
subsection.source: <module name="MatchXpath"> <property name="query" value="//VARIABLE_DEF[./ASSIGN/EXPR/LITERAL_NEW and not(./TYPE/IDENT[@text='var'])]"/> <message key="matchxpath.match" value="New instances should be created via 'var' keyword to avoid duplication of type reference in statement"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that classes (except abstract ones) define a constructor and don't rely on the default one.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="MissingCtor"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that switch statement has a default clause.

Rationale: It's usually a good idea to introduce a default case in every switch statement. Even if the developer is sure that all currently possible cases are covered, this should be expressed in the default branch, e.g. by using an assertion. This way the code is protected against later changes, e.g. introduction of new types in an enumeration type.
This check does not validate any switch expressions. Rationale: The compiler requires switch expressions to be exhaustive. This means that all possible inputs must be covered.

This check does not validate switch statements that use pattern or null labels. Rationale: Switch statements that use pattern or null labels are checked by the compiler for exhaustiveness. This means that all possible inputs must be covered.

See the
Java Language Specification for more information about switch statements and expressions.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="MissingSwitchDefault"/>
subsection.p: Example of violation:
Example of correct code:
Example of correct code which does not require default labels:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that for loop control variables are not modified inside the for block. An example is:

Rationale: If the control variable is modified inside the loop body, the program flow becomes more difficult to follow. See
FOR statement specification for more details.
Such loop would be suppressed:
NOTE:The check works with only primitive type variables. The check will not work for arrays used as control variable.An example is

tr.td:
Control whether to check
enhanced for-loop variable.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="ModifiedControlVariable"/>
subsection.p: Example:

By default, This Check validates
Enhanced For-Loop.
Option 'skipEnhancedForLoopVariable' could be used to skip check of variable from Enhanced For Loop.
An example of how to configure the check so that it skips enhanced For Loop Variable is:
subsection.source: <module name="ModifiedControlVariable"> <property name="skipEnhancedForLoopVariable" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks for multiple occurrences of the same string literal within a single file.
Rationale: Code duplication makes maintenance more difficult, so it can be better to replace the multiple occurrences with a constant.

tr.td: Specify the maximum number of occurrences to allow without generating a warning.
Specify RegExp for ignored strings (with quotation marks).

Specify token type names where duplicate strings are ignored even if they don't match ignoredStringsRegexp. This allows you to exclude syntactical contexts like annotations or static initializers from the check.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="MultipleStringLiterals"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check so that it allows two occurrences of each string:
subsection.source: <module name="MultipleStringLiterals"> <property name="allowedDuplicates" value="2"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check so that it ignores ", " and empty strings:
subsection.source: <module name="MultipleStringLiterals"> <property name="ignoreStringsRegexp" value='^(("")|(", "))$'/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
subsection.source: <module name="MultipleStringLiterals"> <property name="ignoreOccurrenceContext" value=""/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that each variable declaration is in its own statement and on its own line.
Rationale: the Java code conventions chapter 6.1 recommends that declarations should be one per line/statement.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that array initialization do not contain a trailing comma. Rationale: JLS allows trailing commas in arrays and enumerations, but does not allow them in other locations. To unify the coding style, the use of trailing commas should be prohibited.
The check demands that there should not be any comma after the last element of an array.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="NoArrayTrailingComma"/>
subsection.p: Which results in the following violations:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that the clone method is not overridden from the Object class.
This check is almost exactly the same as the NoFinalizerCheck.
See Object.clone()

Rationale: The clone method relies on strange, hard to follow rules that are difficult to get right and do not work in all situations. In some cases, either a copy constructor or a static factory method can be used instead of the clone method to return copies of an object. For more information on rules for the clone method and its issues, see Effective Java: Programming Language Guide First Edition by Joshua Bloch pages 45-52.
Below are some rules/reasons why the clone method should be avoided.

ul.li: Classes supporting the clone method should implement the Cloneable interface but the Cloneable interface does not include the clone method. As a result, it doesn't enforce the method override.
The Cloneable interface forces the Object's clone method to work correctly. Without implementing it, the Object's clone method will throw a CloneNotSupportedException.
Non-final classes must return the object returned from a call to super.clone().
Final classes can use a constructor to create a clone which is different from non-final classes.
If a super class implements the clone method incorrectly all subclasses calling super.clone() are doomed to failure.
If a class has references to mutable objects then those object references must be replaced with copies in the clone method after calling super.clone().
The clone method does not work correctly with final mutable object references because final references cannot be reassigned.
If a super class overrides the clone method then all subclasses must provide a correct clone implementation.

subsection.p: Two alternatives to the clone method, in some cases, is a copy constructor or a static factory method to return copies of an object. Both of these approaches are simpler and do not conflict with final fields. They do not force the calling client to handle a CloneNotSupportedException. They also are typed therefore no casting is necessary. Finally, they are more flexible since they can take interface types rather than concrete classes.

Sometimes a copy constructor or static factory is not an acceptable alternative to the clone method. The example below highlights the limitation of a copy constructor (or static factory). Assume Square is a subclass for Shape.
subsection.source: Shape s1 = new Square(); System.out.println(s1 instanceof Square); //true
subsection.p: ...assume at this point the code knows nothing of s1 being a Square that's the beauty of polymorphism but the code wants to copy the Square which is declared as a Shape, its super type...
subsection.source: Shape s2 = new Shape(s1); //using the copy constructor System.out.println(s2 instanceof Square); //false
subsection.p: The working solution (without knowing about all subclasses and doing many casts) is to do the following (assuming correct clone implementation).
subsection.source: Shape s2 = s1.clone(); System.out.println(s2 instanceof Square); //true
subsection.p: Just keep in mind if this type of polymorphic cloning is required then a properly implemented clone method may be the best choice.
Much of this information was taken from Effective Java: Programming Language Guide First Edition by Joshua Bloch pages 45-52. Give Bloch credit for writing an excellent book.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="NoClone"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that enum definition does not contain a trailing comma. Rationale: JLS allows trailing commas in arrays and enumerations, but does not allow them in other locations. To unify the coding style, the use of trailing commas should be prohibited.
The check demands that there should not be any comma after last constant in enum definition.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="NoEnumTrailingComma"/>
subsection.p: Which results in the following violations:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that there is no method finalize with zero parameters.
See Object.finalize()

Rationale: Finalizers are unpredictable, often dangerous, and generally unnecessary. Their use can cause erratic behavior, poor performance, and portability problems. For more information for the finalize method and its issues, see Effective Java: Programming Language Guide Third Edition by Joshua Bloch, §8.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="NoFinalizer"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that there is only one statement per line.
Rationale: It's very difficult to read multiple statements on one line.
In the Java programming language, statements are the fundamental unit of execution. All statements except blocks are terminated by a semicolon. Blocks are denoted by open and close curly braces.

OneStatementPerLineCheck checks the following types of statements: variable declaration statements, empty statements, import statements, assignment statements, expression statements, increment statements, object creation statements, 'for loop' statements, 'break' statements, 'continue' statements, 'return' statements, resources statements (optional).

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="OneStatementPerLine"/>
subsection.p: The following examples will be flagged as a violation:
An example of how to configure the check to treat resources in a try statement as statements to require them on their own line:
subsection.source: <module name="OneStatementPerLine"> <property name="treatTryResourcesAsStatement" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Note: resource declarations can contain variable definitions and variable references (from java9). When property "treatTryResourcesAsStatement" is enabled, this check is only applied to variable definitions. If there are one or more variable references and one variable definition on the same line in resources declaration, there is no violation. The following examples will illustrate difference:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that overloaded methods are grouped together. Overloaded methods have the same name but different signatures where the signature can differ by the number of input parameters or type of input parameters or both.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="OverloadMethodsDeclarationOrder"/>
subsection.p: Example of correct grouping of overloaded methods:
Example of incorrect grouping of overloaded methods:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Ensures that a class has a package declaration, and (optionally) whether the package name matches the directory name for the source file.
Rationale: Classes that live in the null package cannot be imported. Many novice developers are not aware of this.

Packages provide logical namespace to classes and should be stored in the form of directory levels to provide physical grouping to your classes. These directories are added to the classpath so that your classes are visible to JVM when it runs the code.

tr.td: Control whether to check for directory and package name match.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="PackageDeclaration"/>
subsection.p: Let us consider the class AnnotationLocationCheck which is in the directory /com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/annotations/

Example of how the check works when matchDirectoryStructure option is set to false. Let us again consider the AnnotationLocationCheck class located at directory /com/puppycrawl/tools/checkstyle/checks/annotations/ along with the following setup,
subsection.source: <module name="PackageDeclaration"> <property name="matchDirectoryStructure" value="false"/> </module>

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Disallows assignment of parameters.

Rationale: Parameter assignment is often considered poor programming practice. Forcing developers to declare parameters as final is often onerous. Having a check ensure that parameters are never assigned would give the best of both worlds.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="ParameterAssignment"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that references to instance variables and methods of the present object are explicitly of the form "this.varName" or "this.methodName(args)" and that those references don't rely on the default behavior when "this." is absent.
Warning: the Check is very controversial if 'validateOnlyOverlapping' option is set to 'false' and not that actual nowadays.
Rationale:

ol.li: The same notation/habit for C++ and Java (C++ have global methods, so having "this." do make sense in it to distinguish call of method of class instead of global).
Non-IDE development (ease of refactoring, some clearness to distinguish static and non-static methods).

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p: Limitations: Nothing is currently done about static variables or catch-blocks. Static methods invoked on a class name seem to be OK; both the class name and the method name have a DOT parent. Non-static methods invoked on either this or a variable name seem to be OK, likewise.

tr.td: Control whether to check references to fields.
Control whether to check references to methods.
Control whether to check only overlapping by variables or arguments.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the default check:
subsection.source: <module name="RequireThis"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check for fields only:
subsection.source: <module name="RequireThis"> <property name="checkMethods" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check for methods only:
subsection.source: <module name="RequireThis"> <property name="checkFields" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
Note that method call foo(5) does not raise a violation because methods cannot be overlapped in java.
To configure the check to validate for non-overlapping fields and methods:
subsection.source: <module name="RequireThis"> <property name="validateOnlyOverlapping" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
Please, be aware of the following logic, which is implemented in the check:
1) If you arrange 'this' in your code on your own, the check will not raise violation for variables which use 'this' to reference a class field, for example:
2) If method parameter is returned from the method, the check will not raise violation for returned variable/parameter, for example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Restricts the number of return statements in methods, constructors and lambda expressions. Ignores specified methods (equals by default).
max property will only check returns in methods and lambdas that return a specific value (Ex: 'return 1;').

maxForVoid property will only check returns in methods, constructors, and lambdas that have no return type (IE 'return;'). It will only count visible return statements. Return statements not normally written, but implied, at the end of the method/constructor definition will not be taken into account. To disallow "return;" in void return type methods, use a value of 0.
Rationale: Too many return points can mean that code is attempting to do too much or may be difficult to understand.

tr.td: Specify maximum allowed number of return statements in non-void methods/lambdas.
Specify maximum allowed number of return statements in void methods/constructors/lambdas.

subset of tokens
CTOR_DEF , METHOD_DEF , LAMBDA .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.source: <module name="ReturnCount"> <property name="max" value="3"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check so that it doesn't allow any return statements per void method:
subsection.source: <module name="ReturnCount"> <property name="maxForVoid" value="0"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
subsection.source: <module name="ReturnCount"> <property name="max" value="2"/> <property name="maxForVoid" value="1"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check so that it doesn't allow more than three return statements per method for all methods:
subsection.source: <module name="ReturnCount"> <property name="max" value="3"/> <property name="format" value="^$"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check so that it doesn't allow any return statements in constructors, more than one return statement in all lambda expressions and more than two return statements in methods:
subsection.source: <module name="ReturnCount"> <property name="maxForVoid" value="0"/> <property name="tokens" value="CTOR_DEF"/> </module> <module name="ReturnCount"> <property name="max" value="1"/> <property name="tokens" value="LAMBDA"/> </module> <module name="ReturnCount"> <property name="max" value="2"/> <property name="tokens" value="METHOD_DEF"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks for over-complicated boolean expressions. Currently, it finds code like if (b == true), b || true, !false, boolean a = q > 12 ? true : false, etc.
Rationale: Complex boolean logic makes code hard to understand and maintain.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="SimplifyBooleanExpression"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks for over-complicated boolean return statements. For example the following code
could be written as
subsection.source: return !valid();
subsection.p: The idea for this Check has been shamelessly stolen from the equivalent PMD rule.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="SimplifyBooleanReturn"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p:
Checks that string literals are not used with == or !=. Since == will compare the object references, not the actual value of the strings, String.equals() should be used. More information can be found
in this article.
Rationale: Novice Java programmers often use code like:
subsection.source: if (x == "something")
subsection.p: when they mean
subsection.source: if ("something".equals(x))

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="StringLiteralEquality"/>
subsection.p: Examples of violations:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that an overriding clone() method invokes super.clone(). Does not check native methods, as they have no possible java defined implementation.
Reference: Object.clone().

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="SuperClone"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that an overriding finalize() method invokes super.finalize(). Does not check native methods, as they have no possible java defined implementation.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="SuperFinalize"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks if unnecessary parentheses are used in a statement or expression. The check will flag the following with warnings:
subsection.source: return (x); // parens around identifier return (x + 1); // parens around return value int x = (y / 2 + 1); // parens around assignment rhs for (int i = (0); i < 10; i++) { // parens around literal t -= (z + 1); // parens around assignment rhs boolean a = (x > 7 && y > 5) // parens around expression || z < 9; boolean b = (~a) > -27 // parens around ~a && (a-- < 30); // parens around expression

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p: The check is not "type aware", that is to say, it can't tell if parentheses are unnecessary based on the types in an expression. The check is partially aware about operator precedence but unaware about operator associativity. It won't catch cases such as:

In the first case, given that a, b, and c are all int variables, the parentheses around a + b are not needed. In the second case, parentheses are required as q, r are of type int and p is of type boolean and removing parentheses will give a compile-time error. Even if q and r were boolean still there will be no violation raised as check is not "type aware".
The partial support for operator precedence includes cases of the following type:

tr.td:
subset of tokens
EXPR , IDENT , NUM_DOUBLE , NUM_FLOAT , NUM_INT , NUM_LONG , STRING_LITERAL , LITERAL_NULL , LITERAL_FALSE , LITERAL_TRUE , ASSIGN , BAND_ASSIGN , BOR_ASSIGN , BSR_ASSIGN , BXOR_ASSIGN , DIV_ASSIGN , MINUS_ASSIGN , MOD_ASSIGN , PLUS_ASSIGN , SL_ASSIGN , SR_ASSIGN , STAR_ASSIGN , LAMBDA , TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_BEGIN , LAND , LOR , LITERAL_INSTANCEOF , GT , LT , GE , LE , EQUAL , NOT_EQUAL , UNARY_MINUS , UNARY_PLUS , INC , DEC , LNOT , BNOT , POST_INC , POST_DEC .

EXPR , IDENT , NUM_DOUBLE , NUM_FLOAT , NUM_INT , NUM_LONG , STRING_LITERAL , LITERAL_NULL , LITERAL_FALSE , LITERAL_TRUE , ASSIGN , BAND_ASSIGN , BOR_ASSIGN , BSR_ASSIGN , BXOR_ASSIGN , DIV_ASSIGN , MINUS_ASSIGN , MOD_ASSIGN , PLUS_ASSIGN , SL_ASSIGN , SR_ASSIGN , STAR_ASSIGN , LAMBDA , TEXT_BLOCK_LITERAL_BEGIN , LAND , LOR , LITERAL_INSTANCEOF , GT , LT , GE , LE , EQUAL , NOT_EQUAL , UNARY_MINUS , UNARY_PLUS , INC , DEC , LNOT , BNOT , POST_INC , POST_DEC .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="UnnecessaryParentheses"/>
subsection.p: Which results in the following violations:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks if unnecessary semicolon is used after type declaration.

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p:
This check is not applicable to nested type declarations,
UnnecessarySemicolonAfterTypeMemberDeclaration is responsible for it.

tr.td:
subset of tokens
CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , ENUM_DEF , ANNOTATION_DEF , RECORD_DEF .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="UnnecessarySemicolonAfterOuterTypeDeclaration"/>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to detect unnecessary semicolon only after top level class definitions:
subsection.source: <module name="UnnecessarySemicolonAfterOuterTypeDeclaration"> <property name="tokens" value="CLASS_DEF"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks if unnecessary semicolon is used after type member declaration.

subsection.name: Notes
subsection.p: This check is not applicable to empty statements (unnecessary semicolons inside methods or init blocks), EmptyStatement is responsible for it.

tr.td:
subset of tokens
CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , ENUM_DEF , ANNOTATION_DEF , VARIABLE_DEF , ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF , STATIC_INIT , INSTANCE_INIT , CTOR_DEF , METHOD_DEF , ENUM_CONSTANT_DEF , COMPACT_CTOR_DEF , RECORD_DEF .
CLASS_DEF , INTERFACE_DEF , ENUM_DEF , ANNOTATION_DEF , VARIABLE_DEF , ANNOTATION_FIELD_DEF , STATIC_INIT , INSTANCE_INIT , CTOR_DEF , METHOD_DEF , ENUM_CONSTANT_DEF , COMPACT_CTOR_DEF , RECORD_DEF .

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="UnnecessarySemicolonAfterTypeMemberDeclaration"/>
subsection.p: Results in following:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks if unnecessary semicolon is in enum definitions. Semicolon is not needed if enum body contains only enum constants.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="UnnecessarySemicolonInEnumeration"/>
subsection.p: Example of violations
Example of good cases

subsection.name: Violation Messages

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks if unnecessary semicolon is used in last resource declaration.

tr.td: Allow unnecessary semicolon if closing paren is not on the same line.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="UnnecessarySemicolonInTryWithResources"/>
subsection.p: Example of violations
To configure the check to detect unnecessary semicolon if closing paren is not on same line
subsection.source: <module name="UnnecessarySemicolonInTryWithResources"> <property name="allowWhenNoBraceAfterSemicolon" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example of exclusion

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks that a local variable is declared and/or assigned, but not used. Doesn't support pattern variables yet. Doesn't check array components as array components are classified as different kind of variables by JLS.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check:
subsection.source: <module name="UnusedLocalVariable"/>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding

subsection.name: Description
subsection.p: Checks the distance between declaration of variable and its first usage. Note : Variable declaration/initialization statements are not counted while calculating length.

tr.td: Specify distance between declaration of variable and its first usage. Values should be greater than 0.
Define RegExp to ignore distance calculation for variables listed in this pattern.
Allow to calculate the distance between declaration of variable and its first usage in the different scopes.
Allow to ignore variables with a 'final' modifier.

subsection.name: Examples
subsection.p: To configure the check with default config:
subsection.source: <module name="VariableDeclarationUsageDistance"/>
subsection.p: Example:
Check can detect a block of initialization methods. If a variable is used in such a block and there are no other statements after variable declaration, then distance = 1.
Case #1:
The distance for the variable "minutes" is 1 even though this variable is used in the fifth method's call.
Case #2:
The distance for the variable "minutes" is 6 because there is one more expression (except the initialization block) between the declaration of this variable and its usage.
To configure the check to set allowed distance:
subsection.source: <module name="VariableDeclarationUsageDistance"> <property name="allowedDistance" value="4"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to ignore certain variables:
subsection.source: <module name="VariableDeclarationUsageDistance"> <property name="ignoreVariablePattern" value="^num$"/> </module>
subsection.p: This configuration ignores variables named "num".
Example:
To configure the check to force validation between scopes:
subsection.source: <module name="VariableDeclarationUsageDistance"> <property name="validateBetweenScopes" value="true"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:
To configure the check to check final variables:
subsection.source: <module name="VariableDeclarationUsageDistance"> <property name="ignoreFinal" value="false"/> </module>
subsection.p: Example:

subsection.name: Violation Messages
subsection.p: All messages can be customized if the default message doesn't suit you. Please see the documentation to learn how to.

subsection.name: Package
subsection.p: com.puppycrawl.tools.checkstyle.checks.coding
